question: Cervical cancer is more common (higher prevalence) among Black women than white women. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is higher in Black women than white women. c. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is the same in white and Black women. d. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is unrelated to the underlying prevalence

conversation.content: Cervical cancer is more common (higher prevalence) among Black women than white women. Using the same Pap smear screening test (sensitivity and specificity 97% and 98% respectively), which of the following would you expect?. a. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is higher in white women than Black women. b. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is higher in Black women than white women. c. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is the same in white and Black women. d. The positive predictive value of the Pap smear screening test is unrelated to the underlying prevalence

Positive predictive value (PPV) depends on the prevalence of the disease. Since cervical cancer prevalence is higher in Black women, the PPV of the Pap smear will be higher in Black women than in white women.

Yes, PPV increases with higher disease prevalence because there are more true positives relative to false positives. Since Black women have a higher prevalence of cervical cancer, the PPV of the Pap smear test will indeed be higher in Black women than in white women.

Certainly. PPV = (sensitivity × prevalence) / [(sensitivity × prevalence) + (1 − specificity) × (1 − prevalence)]. With higher prevalence in Black women, the numerator increases more than the denominator, raising PPV. Therefore, PPV is higher in Black women.
Yes. Since sensitivity and specificity are constant, PPV depends directly on prevalence. Higher prevalence in Black women leads to higher PPV compared to white women.
Can you redo your work and try again?

Given:
- Sensitivity = 97%
- Specificity = 98%
- Prevalence is higher in Black women than white women.

PPV formula:  
PPV = (Sensitivity × Prevalence) / [(Sensitivity × Prevalence) + (1 − Specificity) × (1 − Prevalence)]

Since prevalence is higher in Black women, the numerator (true positives) increases, and the denominator increases less proportionally, resulting in a higher PPV in Black women.
